Review & Explanations:

Section 1: Questions 1-10

Questions 1-4

Choose the correct letter A, B or C.

Example

When will the New Year Party be held?

A. December 29th
B. December 30th
C. December 31st

1

The best place for holding the party is _______________

  • A
  • B
  • C
Answer: B
Listen from here Locate Explain Report

  • The keywords in Q1 are “place” and “party”. We have to know the best place for holding the party .

  • The man mentions the word “venue”, which could be a synonym for “place” in this context. Then, the woman suggest a restaurant; however, the man replies that he thinks the restaurant is too small, and it was not a good choice. Hence, A is not correct.

  • Next, the man suggest to choose their common room, asking “how about our common room on the second floor?”. The woman replies: “Great idea”; in other words, she agrees to choose common room as the place for holding the party. Therefore, the answer is B.

2

How much does everyone should pay?

  • A
  • B
  • C
Answer: A
Listen from here Locate Explain Report

  • The keywords in Q2 are “how much” and “pay”. We have to know the cost that everyone should pay.

  • The woman directly asks the man “how about the cost” and asks if 15 pounds is OK. The man asks again if the cost is 50. However, the woman then confirms that it is 15, and the man replies “Right”, which means he agrees that the cost is 15 pounds. Therefore, the answer is A.

3

How many days should they choose menu in advance?

  • A
  • B
  • C
Answer: C
Listen from here Locate Explain Report

  • The keywords in Q3 are “days” and “choose menu in advance”. We have to know how many days they should choose menu in advance.

  • The man mentions all the keywords, saying “we should choose menu and pay in advance” and asking “how many days in advance?”. He also asks if a week is OK. However, the woman thinks a week is not enough, and they should choose menu at least, seven working days in advance. The man then replies “OK”. Therefore, A is not correct, and the answer is C.

4

How much deposit should they pay in advance?

  • A
  • B
  • C
Answer: A
Listen from here Locate Explain Report

  • The keyword in Q4 is “deposit”. We have to know how much deposit they should pay.

  • The woman mentions all the keywords, asking “how much is the deposit?”. The man then replies “Maybe 80 pounds”; however, the woman thinks it’s a little too much. Hence, B is not correct.

  • Next, the man suggests the deposit should be 70 pounds, and the woman replies “Right”, which means that she agrees to pay 70 pounds. Therefore, the answer is A.

Questions 5-10

Complete the notes below.

Write NO MORE THAN TWO WORDS for each answer.

ORDER MENU
Appetizer Fruit juice

5

6 Roast dinner
Vegetables Vegetable salad: carrot, tomato, patato, corn,

7 , lettuce, cucumber
8 9

Drinks Coffee, 10 , Cola
  • 5 Answer: Tomato soup
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q5 are “Appetizer” and “fruit juice”. We have to know what is included in the appetizer beside fruit juice.

    • We can assume that the answer is a noun or a noun phrase consisting of no more than two words.

    • According to the woman, there was fruit juice and onion soup last year. However, the man wants to change the menu because he did not like that soup. Hence, onion soup is not correct.

    • The woman then suggests to choose tomato soup instead, and the man replies: “Good”. Therefore, the answer is tomato soup.

  • 6 Answer: Main Course
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q6 are “Roast dinner”. We have to know which part of the meal following appetizer.

    • We can assume that the answer is a noun or a noun phrase consisting of no more than two words.

    • The woman directly says that the next one is Main Course. Therefore, the answer is Main Course.

  • 7 Answer: Pea, onion
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q7 are “Vegetable salad”. We have to know the ingredients of this dish.

    • We can assume that the answer is a noun or a noun phrase consisting of no more than two words.

    • The man mentions the keywords “vegetable salad”. Then, he and the woman lists all the ingredients: Carrot and tomato, potato and corn, pea and onion, lettuce and cucumber. Since “carrot, tomato, potato, corn” and “lettuce, cucumber” are already written in the note, the answer is pea, onion.

  • 8 Answer: Dessert
    Locate Explain Report

    • In order to answer Q8, we have to know which part of the meal following vegetables.

    • We can assume that the answer is a noun or a noun phrase consisting of no more than two words.

    • The woman directly says “Then for dessert”; therefore, the answer is dessert.

  • 9 Answer: Chocolate cake
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q9 are “mango pudding”. We have to know what is included in the dessert beside mango pudding.

    • We can assume that the answer is a noun or a noun phrase consisting of no more than two words.

    • First, the woman suggests to choose chocolate cake, and the man replies “Why not?”, which means he agrees to choose this dish. The man then suggests to include ice cream in the menu; however, the woman thinks mango pudding is better. Finally, the man agrees to choose mango pudding and chocolate cake. Since mango pudding is already written in the note, the answer is chocolate cake.

  • 10 Answer: Sprite
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keyword in Q10 are “drinks” and “coffee, cola”. We have to know what is included in drinks along with coffee and cola.

    • We can assume that the answer is a noun or a noun phrase consisting of no more than two words.

    • The woman mentions the keyword, saying that “the last one is drinks”. The man then says that almost everyone likes coffee, and the woman also suggests to choose Sprite and Cola beside coffee. Since “coffee, cola” is already written in the note, the answer is Sprite.

  • 11 Answer: 9:00 a.m.-12:00 a.m./9:00 a.m. to 12:00 a.m./9 a.m. to 12 a.m./9 a.m. -12 a.m.
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q11 are “registration time” and “Saturday”. We have to know what the registration time on Saturday is.

    • We can assume that the answer relates to hours or time.

    • According to the woman, the man can register tomorrow morning. She then directly says that On Saturday, the registration time is from 9 am to 12 am. Therefore, the answer is 9 am - 12 am.

  • 12 Answer: Room 214
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q12 are “Registration position” and “Main Building”. We have to know where the registration position is.

    • We can assume that the answer is a noun or a noun phrase consisting of no more than two words.

    • The man asks “Do you know where the register office is?”; in other words, he asks for the registration position. The woman then replies that it is Room 214 on the second floor of the Main Building. Since the answer consists of no more than two words and/pr a number, the answer is Room 214.

  • 13 Answer: Student Card
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q13 are “bring” and “passport photo”. We have to know what the man should bring along with a passport photo.

    • We can assume that the answer is a noun or a noun phrase consisting of no more than two words.

    • The woman says that the man should take some documents when he goes there; therefore, we would know that they are going to talk about what he should bring. The man then asks if he should bring a fee; however, the woman says that they need not pay any fee. Hence, a fee is not correct.

    • Next, the woman says that the man need to take his Student Card and one passport photo. Since “passport photo” is already written in the note, the answer is Student Card.

No 14 and noise in Computer Centre

  • 14 Answer: smoking
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q14 are “no” and “noise”. We have to know what is not allowed in Computer Centre.

    • We can assume that the answer is a noun or a noun phrase consisting of no more than two words.

    • Thanks to the content of the note, we have known that the information about what is not allowed in Computer Center will follow that about opening hours. First, the two people talk about opening hours. Then, the woman says that There is no smoking and noise in Computer Centre. Since “noise” is already written in the note, the answer is smoking.

  • 15 Answer: (student) locker
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q15 are “put their bags in”. We have to know what students can put their bags in.

    • We can assume that the answer is a noun or a noun phrase consisting of no more than two words.

    • The man mentions the keyword “bag”, asking if he can take his bag into the Computer Centre. The woman then replies that put your bag in the (student) locker. Therefore, the answer is student locker.

  • 16 Answer: reserve
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keyword in Q16 is “computers”. We have to know what students can do with computers.

    • We can assume that the answer is a verb.

    • The man first asks if he may reserve a computer. The woman then replies that he can reserve it - a computer - 3 days in advance. Therefore, the answer is reserve.

  • 17 Answer: photocopier
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keyword in Q17 is “printer”. We have to know what students can use along with a printer.

    • We can assume that the answer is a noun or a noun phrase consisting of no more than two words.

    • The man asks if there is a photocopier or printer in the Computer Centre. The woman then replies “of course”. Since “printer” is already written in the note, the answer is (a) photocopier.

19

  • 18 Answer: B
    Listen from here Explain Report

    • In order to answer Q18, we have to know which building is in the location 18.

    • First, the woman says that the first building the man can see is the Teaching Building, which is the building between A and the Student Union.

    • Then, the woman says that "on your left is a small bookstore". We can infer that building A is that bookstore since the student chose the entrance as a landmark. Then she said that a gym is opposite to the bookstore. Therefore, answer for question 18 is the gym, and the answer is B.

  • 19 Answer: F
    Listen from here Explain Report

    • The man asked where the Computer Centre was. The woman then replied that "it is opposite to the Student Union, between the Library on the left corner and the canteen on your right". There is only one building opposite the Student Union which have the Library on its left, the building with number 19. Therefore, the answer for question 19 is F. Computer Centre .

  • 20 Answer: C
    Listen from here Explain Report

    • After answering question 19, we can easily find the correct answer for question 20. It must be C. canteen .

Questions 21-26

Complete the notes below.

Write NO MORE THAN TWO WORDS AND/OR A NUMBER for each answer.

Dissertation Requirements

Word limitation: 21 words
not includes 22 and contents
Deadline for dissertation 23
Check list of 24
Tutorial time: 1 :00 p.m – 2:00 p.m
on Tuesday 25 on Friday
Printed by 26
  • 21 Answer: 20,000
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q21 are “word limitation”. We have to know the word limitation of dissertation.

    • We can assume that the answer consists of at least one number.

    • Ariel mentions the keywords, asking “what about the word limit?”. The professor then replies that the words of final dissertation of the master degree are limited between 18 to 20 thousand. In other words, word limitation is 18000-20000. Therefore, the answer is 20000.

  • 22 Answer: acknowledgement
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q22 are “not includes”. We have to know what is not included in the word along with contents.

    • We can assume that the answer is a noun or a noun phrase consisting of no more than two words.

    • Ariel asks if it includes words of references. The professor then replies “Yes”; therefore, words of references and references are all not correct.

    • Next, according to the professor, the word does not include the acknowledgement and contents. Since “contents” is already written in the note, the answer is (the) acknowledgement.

  • 23 Answer: 30th July
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keyword in Q23 is “deadline”.

    • We can assume that the answer is a date.

    • Sky directly asks when the hand-in date is. Note that to “hand in” means to give something to someone. In other words, Sky is asking when he have to submit the dissertation - the deadline. The professor then replies that The deadline is on the 30th of July. Therefore, the answer is 30th July.

  • 24 Answer: tutor arrangements
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q24 are “check list”. We have to know what list students should check.

    • We can assume that the answer is a noun or a noun phrase consisting of no more than two words.

    • The professor mentions all the keywords, saying that Ariel and Sky can check the lists of tutor arrangements. Therefore, the answer is tutor arrangements.

  • 25 Answer: 2:00 p.m.-3:00 p.m/2:00 p.m. to 3:00 p.m./2 p.m. to 3 p.m.
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keyword in Q25 are “tutorial” and “Friday”. We have to know the tutorial time on Friday.

    • We can assume that the answer is a period of time.

    • Thanks to the content of the note, we have known that the tutorial time is from 1pm to 2pm on Tuesday. The professor then says that the other is from 2pm to 3pm on Friday. Therefore, the answer is 2pm - 3pm.

  • 26 Answer: laser printer
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keyword in Q26 is “printed by”. We have to know what students would use to print their dissertation.

    • We can assume that the answer is a noun or a noun phrase consisting of no more than two words.

    • The professor directly says that Sky and Ariel must print their work by laser printer. Therefore, the answer is laser printer.

F Write up work

References

Draft plan

28

29

30

  • 27 Answer: B
    Listen from here Explain Report

    • In order to answer Q27, we have to know the first stage in the dissertation timetable.

    • First, the professor says: “let’s talk about the dissertation timetable”. Then, he says that the first point is to choose the topic. This means the first stage in the timetable is to choose the topic; therefore, the answer is B.

  • 28 Answer: A
    Listen from here Explain Report

    • In order to answer Q28, we have to know the stage after “Draft plan” in the dissertation timetable.

    • Sky and the professor mentions the draft plan. Ariel then asks If the draft is OK, what they should do next, and the professor replies that they will begin to do research to collect data. Therefore, the next step is to do research, and the answer is A.

  • 29 Answer: F
    Listen from here Explain Report

    • In order to answer Q29, we have to know the stage after “Do research” in the dissertation timetable.

    • The professor says that when Ariel and Sky’s data is enough for their work, they will begin to write up their dissertation. This means when they finish doing research in order to collect data, they will begin write up work. Therefore, the answer is F.

  • 30 Answer: E
    Listen from here Explain Report

    • In order to answer Q30, we have to know the stage after “Write up work” and before “Hand in work” in the dissertation timetable.

    • Ariel asks if they can hand their dissertation in after they finish writing up their work; however, the professor says that they should do proof-reading before handing in. Therefore, the stage after “Write up work” and before “Hand in work” in the dissertation timetable is proof-reading, and the answer is E.

Questions 31-40

Complete the notes below.

Write NO MORE THAN THREE WORDS AND/OR A NUMBER for each answer.

The driest continent is 31

The Australia is about 32 times larger than Britain.

Three main structural features of Australia:

The Great Western Plateau The Central Eastern Lowlands

The 33

The hottest month of Australia is 34

The flag of Australia indicates its historical relationship with 35

English is Australia’s official language just by 36 not by law.

37 of Australian are migrants.

Australian employees have paid annual leave; sick leave and 38

Australia’s own history and culture are mainly affected by the 39

The Australian government carried a 40 policy to finance arts.

  • 31 Answer: Antarctica
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q31 are “driest continent”. We have to know the name of the driest continent.

    • We can assume that the answer is a noun or a noun phrase consisting of no more than three words.

    • According to the speaker, Australia is the second driest continent after Antarctica. In other words, Antarctica is the driest continent, and Australia is the second. Therefore, the answer is Antarctica.

  • 32 Answer: 25
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q32 are “times” and “Britain”. We have to know how large Australia is compared to Britain.

    • We can assume that the answer is a number or a number written in no more than three words.

    • According to the speaker, Australia is about 25 times larger than Britain. Therefore, the answer is 25 or twenty five.

  • 33 Answer: Eastern Highlands
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q33 are “three main structural features ”. We have to know the last feature of Australia.

    • We can assume that the answer is a noun or a noun phrase consisting of no more than three words.

    • The speaker mentions all the keywords, saying that there are three main structural characters. Note that “character” could be a synonym for “feature” in this context. The speaker then lists all three parts: the first one is the Great Western Plateau, the Central Eastern Lowlands, the last one is the Eastern Highlands. Therefore, the answer is Eastern Highlands.

  • 34 Answer: January
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q34 are “hottest month”. We have to know the hottest month of Australia.

    • We can assume that the answer is the name of a month.

    • According to the speaker, for most of the country -Australia-, January usually is the hottest month in summer. Therefore, January is the hottest month of Australia, and the answer is January.

  • 35 Answer: Britain
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q35 are “flag” and “historical relationship”. We have to know the flag of Australia indicates its historical relationship with which country or region.

    • We can assume that the answer is a noun or a noun phrase consisting of no more than three words.

    • The speaker mentions the phrase “the flag of Australia”. He then says that The small Union Jack (in the flag) represents the historical link with Britain. Note that to “represent” and to “indicate” both means to “show” something in this context, while “link” could be a synonym for “relationship”. Therefore, the flag of Australia indicates the historical relationship with Britain, and the answer is Britain.

  • 36 Answer: usage
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q36 are “English” and “law”.

    • We can assume that the answer is a noun or a noun phrase consisting of no more than three words.

    • According to the speaker, the official language is English – by usage, not law. In other words, English is Australia’s official language just by usage, not by law. Therefore, the answer is usage.

  • 37 Answer: 1/4 / 25 percent
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q37 are “Australian” and “migrants”.

    • We can assume that the answer is a proportion.

    • The speaker says that Australia is a multicultural society with about a quarter of the population foreign-born. Note that a person who is “foreign born” is also “migrant”. Therefore, a quarter of the population foreign-born means that a quarter of Australian are migrant. Therefore, the answer is a quarter.

  • 38 Answer: long-service leave
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q38 are “paid” and “annual leave, sick leave”. We have to know which kind of paid leave Australian employees can get.

    • We can assume that the answer is a noun or a noun phrase consisting of no more than three words.

    • Note that “leave” means “time allowed away from work”. The speaker mentions all the keywords, saying that employees can get paid annual leave, sick leave and long-service leave. Since “annual leave, sick leave” is already written in the note, the answer is long-service leave.

  • 39 Answer: Asian neighbours/Asian neighbors
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q39 are “history and culture” and “mainly affected”. We have to know the best form of garlic to use.

    • We can assume that the answer is a noun or a noun phrase consisting of no more than three words.

    • The speaker first says that many aspects of the arts in Australia have their roots in Europe; however, we have to find information about history and culture, not arts. Hence, Europe is not correct.

    • Then, the speaker says that Australia’s Asian neighbours have made a main impact on its own history and culture. In other words, Australia’s own history and culture are mainly affected by its Asian neighbours. Therefore, the answer is Asian neighbours or Asian neighbors.

  • 40 Answer: tax deduction
    Listen from here Locate Explain Report

    • The keywords in Q40 are “policy” and “finance arts”. We have to know which kind of policy the Australian government carried in order to finance arts.

    • We can assume that the answer is a noun or a noun phrase consisting of no more than three words.

    • According to the speaker, the Australian government has developed tax deduction policies to encourage greater financial support of the arts. Note that to “finance” arts means to provide money for arts. In other words, the Australian government has carried tax deduction policies to finance - support financially - arts. Therefore, the answer is tax deduction.

SECTION 1

Woman: Hi, Sam. Let’s try and get it sorted out today, OK?

Man: Yeah, sure. It’s time we started working out the details.

Woman: Exactly. What should we begin with?

Man: Date.

Woman: OK. When is the best time to hold the New Year’s Party?

Man: How about the 30th of December ?

Woman: I’m afraid that’s a bit late.

Man: Yeah, the day before?

Woman: Fine. 29th of December.

Man: And what about a venue?

Woman: In a restaurant? Which restaurant were we in last year?

Man: Let me think. It is tulip garden. But I don’t think it was a good choice.

Woman: Why?

Man: The venue is too small. And we have about 30 people more than last year.

Woman: You are right.

Man: So how about our common room on the second floor?

Woman: Great idea.

Man: And then let’s think about invitations…

Woman: All staff and all students.

Man: How about last year students?

Woman: What do you mean?

Man: I know someone who has graduated already but still stay in the city, he might, want to come to the next month’s Graduation ceremony .

Woman: Fine. I will confirm the person later.

Man: Right.

Woman: How about the cost? 15 pounds, is that OK?

Man: What? Fifty?

Woman: No, fifteen.

Man: Right.

Woman: The next one is the food and drink. In my mind, it’s better for us to book them from a restaurant.

Man: Definitely. Which one do you prefer?

Woman: How about Tulip Garden?

Man: OK. And we should choose menu and pay in advance by deposit . How many days in advance? A week?

Woman: A week is not enough. I think at least, seven working days.

Man: OK.

Woman: How much is the deposit?

Man: I’m not sure. Maybe 80 pounds ?

Woman: I think it’s a little too much.

Man: Seventy pounds?

Woman: Right.

Woman: Well, let’s talk about the menu.

Man: Yes. Appetizer first. What was it last year?

Woman: I remember there was fruit juice and onion soup. Do you want to change?

Man: Yes. I didn’t like that soup.

Woman: Maybe we can order tomato soup instead of onion soup. Is that OK?

Man: Good.

Woman: And the next one is Main Course.

Man: How about, chicken or beef?

Woman: I prefer roast, dinner.

Man: Good idea.

Woman: And the third one is vegetables how about .

Man: How.about a vegetable salad?

Woman: Fine. What vegetables do you prefer?

Man: Carrot and tomato?

Woman: Yeah, and potato and corn?

Man: Yes. I like corn. It is good for the eyes.

Woman: Really?

Man: Yes.

Woman: And pea and onion…

Man: OK. And how about lettuce and cucumber ?

Woman: Yes. Ladies usually like that.

Man: That’s perfect.

Woman: Then for dessert, how about traditional chocolate cake?

Man: Why not? And ice cream?

Woman: I think mango pudding is better.

Man: OK. Mango pudding and chocolate cake.

Woman: The last one is drinks.

Man: I think almost everyone likes coffee.

Woman: Yes. And Sprite and Cola?

Man: Fine.

Woman: Do you think if we should prepare for some souvenirs ?

Man: We can take some photos, print them and give them to all people at the end of the party as a memory .

Woman: Good idea.

SECTION 2

Man: Hi, Mary, how are things going?

Woman: Fine. And you?

Man: Actually, I’m worried about the Computer Centre.

Woman: What’s the matter?

Man: Because I didn’t attend the Computer Centre meeting yesterday.

Woman: I can tell you the information about it.

Man: Really? You are so nice.

Woman: Well, What do you want to know?

Man: Err.. when is the registration time of Computer Centre?

Woman: It is at 9:00 a.m.-4:00 p.m. from Monday to Friday this week.

Mạn: Today is Friday, right?

Woman: Yes.

Man: Oh, no.

Woman: Don’t worry. You can register tomorrow morning.

Man: But. tomorrow is Saturday.

Woman: Yes. On Saturday, the registration time is 9 a.m. to 12 a.m.

Man: That’s so great.

Woman: Yes.

Man: Do you know where the register office is?

Woman: Yes. Room 214 on the second floor of the Main Building.

Man: Two forty or fourteen?

Woman: Fourteen. And you should take some documents when you go there.

Man: What kind of documents? A fee?

Woman: No. We are registered students, so we needn’t pay any fee.

Man: Great.

Woman: You need to take your Student Card and one passport photo.

Man: OK.

Woman: And on the meeting, the lecturer told us some rules of the Computer Centre we have to know.

Man: What kind of rules? Is that very important?

Woman: Yes. The first, one is opening hours.

Man: I hope it closes late.

Woman: Right. It opens at 9 o'clock as usual, and closes at 11 in the evening.

Man: Perfect.

Woman: There is no smoking and noise in Computer Centre.

Man: Fine. Can I take some snacks?

Woman: You can only eat something in the lounge.

Man: Then, can I take my bag into the Computer Centre?

Woman: There is a student locker in the lounge . You may put your bag in the locker. So do remember to take a lock.

Man: Fine.

Woman: And do not occupy a locker for more than 3 days.

Man: Yes. May I reserve a computer?

Woman: Yes. There is a reservation system in the Computer Centre. You can reserve it three days in advance.

Man: Fine. I’d like to know if there is a photocopier or printer in the Computer Centre.

Woman: Of course. On the second floor. But, remember to take your Student Card.

Man: Why?

Woman: Because none of the machines take coins.

Man: Fine.

Woman: And do not use them ten minutes before the centre is closed.

Man: Alright.

Man: Well, can you tell me where the Computer Centre is? In the main campus ?

Woman: Do you have a campus map?

Man: No.

Woman: Well. I will draw a map for you. Do you have a pen?

Man: Yes.

Woman: Well, this is the entrance , and the first, building you can see is the Teaching Building.

Man: Yes.

Woman: On your left is a small bookstore of our university.

Man: Great. I just want to buy some books and CDs.

Woman: Then, go east, and you can see a small gym opposite to the bookstore.

Woman: Sorry, I don’t know.

Woman: On the other side is the Student Union. And. there is a lab on the east side of it.

Man: If I want to join some societies I can go the Student Union, right?

Woman: Right,

Woman: Yes. It is near to lab and not far from the Teaching Building.

Woman: Sorry, I’m not sure, maybe five pounds per hour.

Woman: It is opposite to the Student Union between the Library on the left corner and the canteen on your right.

SECTION 3

Professor: Good morning, everyone. Today, I’d like to give you an opportunity to ask questions about requirements and timetable on writing your final dissertation . So anything you’d like to ask first?

Ariel: Professor, what about the word limit?

Professor: Well, you know generally, the words of final dissertation of the master degree are limited between 18 to 20 thousand.

Ariel: Oh, does that include words of references?

Professor: Yes. Of course.

Sky: And contents?

Professor: No. The word does not include the acknowledgement and contents.

Sky: What is acknowledgement?

Professor: It is a few words of thanks that you write at the beginning of the dissertation to the people who have helped you.

Ariel: How about its words?

Professor: No more than a hundred words .

Ariel: Right.

Sky: Professor, when is the hand-in date?

Professor: The deadline is on the 30th of July .

Sky: Is it a fixed hand-in date? I mean if I cannot hand in my work before 30th July, how…?

Professor: Sky, I’m afraid that you have to hand in your work on time unless that you have some sort of accidents or okay .

Sky: OK.

Ariel: How do I hand in my work?

Professor: You could give your work to your tutor at the tutorial or send email to department.

Sky: Professor, when can I know who my tutor is?

Professor: You can check the lists of tutor arrangements.

Sky: ‘ Online?

Professor: Yes. Or you could go to our department office to check.

Ariel: Fine.

Ariel: How many tutorials do we have in a week?

Professor: Usually, there are two tutorials per week.

Ariel: How long do they last? Two hours?

Professor: No. One hour on afternoons.

Sky: Both on weekends?

Professor: No. One is from 1 p.m. to 2 p.m. on Tuesday the other is from 2 p.m. to 3 p.m. on Friday.

Ariel: How about the requirements for the format?

Professor: You can check the requirements online, but one of the most important things is to have a printer .

Ariel: Printer?

Professor: Yes. We usually keep all dissertations on file, so you must print your work by laser printer.

Ariel: Fine.

Professor: Let’s talk about the dissertation timetable .

Ariel: OK.

Professor: On the first week of May you should begin to prepare for writing. The first point is to choose the topic.

Ariel: Can we choose the topic by ourselves?

Professor: Of course. Your tutor will give you some suggestions and you can narrow a topic by yourself.

Ariel: Great.

Professor: And then you can work on your basic references.

Ariel: Right.

Professor: You can ask your tutor to give you a reference list and then borrow reference books from our library.

Sky: And the next point is to prepare for the draft plan?

Professor: Definitely. You should write a draft first and then discuss it with your tutor at tutorial.

Ariel: If the draft is OK, what should we do next?

Professor: You will begin to do research to collect data to support your work.

Ariel: OK.

Ariel: Can we choose the research methods by ourselves?

Professor: It is better for you to take your tutor’s advice.

Ariel: OK.

Professor: When your data is enough for your work you will begin to write up your dissertation.

Sky: How many parts does a dissertation contain ?

Professor: Usually, your work must have introduction, main body and a conclusion . You should talk about it with your tutor.

Ariel: And then can we hand our dissertation in?

Professor: No. You should do proof-reading before handing in your work.

Ariel: OK.

Professor: Anything else?

Ariel: No.

Professor: Right.

SECTION 4

Australia is the world’s smallest continents and largest island. It is one of the oldest land masses and flattest of the continents. After Antarctica, Australia is the second driest continent. Most areas of Australia are semi desert or arid. Almost 40 per cent is north of the Tropic of Capricorn. On its western coast is the Indian Ocean and on its east the Coral and Tasman seas of the South Pacific Ocean. Australia is the only nation which occupies an entire continent. It is about 25 times larger than Britain and almost double the combined areas of Pakistan and India. There are three main structural characters: the first one is the Great Western Plateau. It covers most of Western Australia, much of the Northern Territory and South Australia, and part of western Queensland. Its average elevation is about 300m. East of the plateau, extending from the Gulf of Carpentaria in the north to eastern South Australia and the western and Victorian coast , is the great lowland belt known as the Central Eastern Lowlands. The belt’s average elevation is 150m and, at Lake Eyre in South Australia, it drops to about twelve metres below sea level. The last one is the Eastern Highlands, better known as the Great dividing Range, following the eastern coast south from far northern Queensland to southern Tasmania , nearly over 400 kilometres from the coast and sometimes forming part of it. Their average altitude is less than 910m although peaks exceed 1,800 metres in the rugged south-eastern area, called the Australian Alps.

Nearly a third of Australia is north of the Tropic of Capricorn and the rest is the temperate zone. Low rainfall and clear sky is a feature of the climate on most of the continent. In Australia summer is from December to February, autumn , March to May, winter, June to August, and spring, September to November. For most of the country, January usually is the hottest month in summer. The flag of Australia is the only one to fly over a whole continent. The small union Jack represents the historical link with Britain, the large star has six points for each of the states and one star for the territories , and the small stars form the Southern Cross – a prominent feature of the southern hemisphere night sky.

Australia has no official or traditional national costume. Green and gold have been used traditionally by Australian Olympic and other sporting teams for most of the 20th century, and have became the national colours formally in 1984. The official language is English – by usage, not law. It has its own colloquialisms and slang but does not differ importantly from other forms of English, except, in accent. Spelling generally follows the British form. Australia is one of the most urbanized countries in the world, with about 70% of the population living in the 10 largest cities and only 15 per cent of Australians live in rural areas. Australians have a high standard of living by world standards. Australia is a multicultural society with about a quarter of the population foreign-born . The first European settlement of the continent by the British – began in 1788 , on the site now occupied by Sydney. Settlement schemes during the next 150 years helped increase Australia’s population to about 7.4 million by the end of World War II. Over 5 million migrants have settled in Australia since, helping to more than double its post-war population. Nowadays, most Australians work for wage or salary. They usually work about 35-40 hours per week. Employees can get paid annual leave (about 4 weeks), sick leave and long-service leave. They also have about 10 paid public holidays per year. Most people retire at the age of 60-65. The average Australian female has a life expectancy of about 79 and the male about 73. Most Australians many in their late 20s. On average, couples have two to three children .

Many aspects of the arts in Australia have their roots in Europe, but its Asian neighbours have made a main impact on its own history and culture. Distinctively, Australian trends are developing, and the vigor and originality of the arts in Australia often surprise visitors. In the late 1970s and early 1980s the great problem facing the arts was the same in other nations-increased costs and a decrease in government financing . But increasing public interest provided the momentum to carry them through difficult times. The Australian government has developed tax deduction policies to encourage greater financial support of the arts. A tax deduction is available for donations of property to public libraries, museums and art galleries . The Australia council is a funding agency of the government. The agency spends over fifty million dollars per year. More is spent by state governments. The Australia council board supports specific art forms and central council programmes support research, education and multicultural arts.
